article.paragraph: Economy of CanadaTransportation in Canada, the world's second-largest country in total area, is predicated on efficient, high-capacity multimodaltransportspanning often vast distances betweenGeography of Canadanatural resource extraction sites,Agriculture in CanadaagriculturalandList of census metropolitan areas and agglomerations in Canadaurban areas.Canada's transportation system includes more thanconvert1400000kmof roads, 10 major international airports, 300 smaller airports,convert72093kmonof functioning railway track, and more than 300 commercial ports and harbours that provide access to thePacific OceanPacific,Atlantic OceanAtlanticandArctic OceanArcticoceans as well as theGreat Lakesand theSt. Lawrence Seaway.cite webhttp://www41.statcan.ca/2007/4006/ceb4006_000_e.htmTransportation in CanadaStatistics Canada2008-03-26In 2005, the transportation sector made up 4.2% of Canada's GDP, compared to 3.7% for Canada's mining and oil and gas extraction industries.cite webhttp://www.statcan.ca/english/research/11-621-MIE/11-621-MIE2006044.pdfAn Analysis of the Transportation Sector in 2005Statistics Canada2008-03-27PDFhttp://web.archive.org/web/20080409105655/http://www.statcan.ca/english/research/11-621-MIE/11-621-MIE2006044.pdf2008-04-09

Transport Canadaoverseas and regulates most aspects of transportation within federal jurisdiction, including interprovincial transport. This primarily includes rail, air and maritime transportation. Transport Canada is under the direction of the federal government'sMinister of Transport (Canada)Minister of Transport. TheTransportation Safety Board of Canadais responsible for maintaining transportation safety in Canada by investigating accidents and making safety recommendations.

article.heading: History
European contact
article.paragraph: Aboriginal peoples in Canada, relied oncanoes,kayaks,umiaksandBull Boats, in addition to thesnowshoe,tobogganandsledin winter for transportation prior to European contact. Europeans adopted these technologies as they pushed deeper into the continent's interior, and were thus able to travel via the waterways that fed from theSt. Lawrence RiverandHudson Bay.Virtual Vault, an online exhibition of Canadian historical art at Library and Archives Canada

In the 19th century and early 20th century transportation relied on harnessing oxen toRed River ox cartsor horse to waggon. Maritime transportation was via manual labour such as canoe or wind on sail. Water or land travel speeds was approximatelyconvert8to15km/h0on.cite webRodrigueDr. Jean-PaulHistorical Geography of Transportation - Part IDept. of Economics & GeographyHofstra University19982008http://people.hofstra.edu/geotrans/eng/ch1en/conc1en/ch1c3_1en.html2008-01-18http://web.archive.org/web/20080112113050/http://people.hofstra.edu/geotrans/eng/ch1en/conc1en/ch1c3_1en.html2008-01-12

Settlement was along river routes. Agricultural commodities were perishable, and trade centres were withinconvert50km0on. Rural areas centred around villages, and they were approximatelyconvert10km0onapart. The advent ofSteam locomotivesteam railwaysandSteamboatsteamshipsconnected resources and markets of vast distances in the late 19th century.Railways also connected city centres, in such a way that the traveller went by sleeper, railway hotel, to the cities. Crossing the country by train took four or five days, as it still does by car. People generally lived withinconvert5mi0onof thedowntowncore thus the train could be used for inter-city travel and thetramfor commuting.
The advent of the interstate or Trans-Canada Highway in Canada in 1963 established ribbon development, truck stops, and industrial corridors along throughways.

article.paragraph: The Federal Department of Transport (established 2 November 1936) supervised railways, canals, harbours, marine and shipping, civil aviation, radio and meteorology. The Transportation Act of 1938 and the amended Railway Act, placed control and regulation of carriers in the hands of the Board of Transport commissioners for Canada. The Royal Commission on Transportation was formed 29 December 1948, to examine transportation services to all areas of Canada to eliminate economic or geographic disadvantages. The Commission also reviewed the Railway Act to provide uniform yet competitive freight-rates.
